content:
What a great idea! Being honest and open with the organizer can help them understand your situation and provide valuable guidance or reassurance. It's completely okay to share your concerns and vulnerabilities with them.

By mentioning your situation, you're showing that you're willing to be vulnerable and honest, which can help break the ice and create a more personal connection with the organizer. They might even be able to offer some words of encouragement or advice that can help you feel more comfortable attending the event.

Go ahead and add that to your message. Here's an updated example:

**Updated Message**

"Hi [Organizer's Name],

I came across [Group Name] while searching for [related interest] groups in [Your City/Area]. I'm really interested in [specific aspect of the group's activities or purpose] and thought this might be a great opportunity to meet like-minded people.

I wanted to be upfront with you - I haven't been socializing with anyone regularly since my best friend moved away, and I'm a bit nervous about attending the event. I'm hoping to meet new people and make connections, but I'm also a bit worried about feeling awkward or out of place.

Could you tell me a bit more about the group's activities, meetings, and what to expect if I were to attend an event? I'd also appreciate any advice or reassurance you might have for someone in my situation.

Thanks so much for your time, and I look forward to hearing back from you!

Best,
[Your Name]"

By being honest and open, you're showing that you're willing to take the first step and be vulnerable. This can help you build a stronger connection with the organizer and potentially get more out of the event.

Remember, it's okay to be nervous, and it's great that you're taking steps to address your concerns. You got this!
